item.title: Putin expected in Tianjin for summit hosted by China
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin is expected to land in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin to attend a summit hosted by counterpart Xi Jinping with around 20 other world leaders.

item.title: Review: Kneecap at EP - a sort of homecoming
item.description: Kneecap delivered a blistering set at Electric Picnic this afternoon, as they took to the main stage at Stradbally for their very first time.

item.title: Preview: Ireland must keep eyes on prize against Spain
item.description: Scott Bemand did his best to deny it, but it's hard to shake the feeling that Ireland are coming into Sunday's Rugby World Cup Pool C game against Spain with one eye on next week against New Zealand.

item.title: Watch: Fans react to Kneecap at Electric Picnic
item.description: Kneecap performed on the main stage at Electric Picnic this afternoon to a huge crowd.

item.title: Family of Norwegian hiker who died in Manitoba 'meeting the people he loved' as they retrace his steps
item.description: The family of a Norwegian hiker who died in northern Manitoba landed in Winnipeg on Friday to embark on a trip that retraces their late son's Canadian journey, and to meet the people who embraced him along the way.

item.title: Houthis say PM killed in Israeli strike on Thursday
item.description: Yemen's Houthi rebels have said their prime minister had been killed in an Israeli airstrike, the most senior official known to have died in a series of attacks during the Gaza war.

item.title: Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker Parubiy shot dead
item.description: Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy has been shot dead in the western city of Lvivon, with a search under way for the killer.

item.title: Ancient tombs unearthed in Iraq due to drought
item.description: Archaeologists in drought-hit Iraq have discovered 40 ancient tombs after water levels in the country's largest reservoir declined, an antiquities official has said.

item.title: Athlone see off Red Star to keep Euro campaign alive
item.description: Athlone Town kept their European campaign alive with a 2-0 win over Serbian champions Crvena Zvedza in Enschede, Netherlands with the Midlanders booking a spot in the first qualifying round of the inaugural Women's Europa Cup.

item.title: UNIFIL peacekeping mission to end southern Lebanon
item.description:
Following the UN Security Council's decision to end its peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon, Bishop César Essayan, Apostolic Vicar of Beirut, expresses concern over the effects of the decision while hoping for 'a dignified peace' in Ukraine and the Middle East.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo meets with President Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets with the President of Zimbabwe, Emmerson Mnangagwa, for a private audience in the Vatican’s Apostolic Palace.

Read all

item.title: When peace considered impossible became reality
item.description:
On the anniversary of the ceasefire declared by the IRA on 31 August 1994, which marked a crucial turning point in the peace process in Northern Ireland, we republish excerpts from a speech given last April at Queen's University in Belfast by one of the protagonists of the Good Friday Agreement signed on 10 April 1998, former US Senator George J. Mitchell.

Read all

item.title: Marking the 31st anniversary of the ceasefire in Northern Ireland
item.description:
On 31 August 1994 the IRA publicly announced a ceasefire, a crucial step on the way to the landmark 1998 Good Friday Agreement that brought an end to the Troubles in Northern Ireland.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo to open Augustinian General Chapter on September 1
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV will preside at the opening Mass for the General Chapter of the Order of St. Augustine on September 1 in the Basilica of St. Augustine in Campo Marzio, Rome.

Read all

item.title: Battle lines drawn for Fianna Fáil presidential contest
item.description: Some of those who worked with Jim Gavin in the Irish Air Corps recall his exceptional map reading ability - a skill he will need to deploy again in the coming weeks, writes Political Correspondent Mícheál Lehane.

item.title: TV chef Gordon Ramsay reveals skin cancer treatment
item.description: TV chef Gordon Ramsay has said he has undergone treatment to remove skin cancer, thanking "incredible" health workers for their efforts.

item.title: Houthis in Yemen say PM of rebel-controlled government killed in Israeli airstrike
item.description: The Iran-backed Houthis said Saturday an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government in the Yemeni capital of Sanaa. Ahmed al-Rahawi died Thursday along with a number of ministers, according to a statement.

item.title: U.S. criticized for denying Mahmoud Abbas visa to attend UN as Palestinian statehood set for discussion
item.description: The U.S. says it won't allow Mahmoud Abbas entry to the U.S., where he was set to attend a world leaders' gathering in New York City at the United Nations, prompting a spokesperson for the Palestinian president to call for Washington to reverse its decision. Canada and several other countries have said they're prepared to recognize Palestinian statehood at the meeting.

item.title: Ambassador contacts German officials over protest assault
item.description: The Irish ambassador to Germany has conveyed her concern to German authorities after an Irish demonstrator was assaulted by police officers during a pro-Palestine protest in Berlin.

item.title: Remains of hostage returned from Gaza identified - Israel
item.description: The remains of the second of two hostages recovered from Gaza this week have been identified as belonging to the student Idan Shtivi, the Israeli prime minister's office has said.

item.title: Canada crushes Wales 42-0, advances to quarterfinals at Women's Rugby World Cup
item.description: Canada and Scotland advanced to the Women's Rugby World Cup quarterfinals on Saturday, Scotland for the first time since 1998.

item.title: Taoiseach backs Jim Gavin's FF presidential candidate bid
item.description: Taoiseach and Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin has endorsed former Dublin GAA football manager Jim Gavin as the party's candidate in the upcoming Presidential Election.

item.title: Warning over MDMA pills in circulation at Electric Picnic
item.description: The Health Service Executive has issued a warning about high strength MDMA pills in circulation at the Electric Picnic festival.

item.title: Haiti: Irish missionary, orphanage staff, 3-year-old released after abduction
item.description:
An Irish missionary has been released from captivity in Haiti, along with 6 orphanage staff and a 3-year-old child, following a kidnap ordeal that lasted nearly a month.

Read all

item.title: Moscow says it hit homes, infrastructure in Ukraine, Kyiv says it struck Russian refineries
item.description: As Russia and Ukraine traded attacks in the war that began in February 2022, Volodymyr Zelenskyy noted the deadline U.S. President Donald Trump gave for deciding on new measures against Russia if Vladimir Putin fails to commit to a meeting with the Ukrainian leader. "Two weeks will be on Monday. And we will remind everybody," Zelenskyy said.

item.title: Man charged over assault on English tourist in Dublin
item.description: A 22-year old man has appeared before Dublin District Court charged in connection with the serious assault of an English tourist in Temple Bar in Dublin earlier this month.

item.title: One dead, 24 injured after Russian attack in Ukraine
item.description: A "massive" overnight Russian attack on central and southeastern Ukraine killed one person and injured at least 24 others, authorities have said.

item.title: EU urges US to reconsider ban on Palestinian officials
item.description: European Union foreign ministers have urged the United States to reconsider its decision not to allow Palestinian officials to take part in the UN General Assembly in New York, EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas has said.

item.title: Reducing immigration unlikely to help housing crisis
item.description: The bedrock of any Government's planning is demographics and the number of people living in a country and a reliable forecast for population growth are vital.

item.title: Did Israel target journalists killed in Gaza this week?
Rise and rule - 50th anniversary of de Valera's death
Young Ukrainians doubtful about prospects for peace
item.description: In a week when Russian forces returned to bombing Kyiv with missiles and drones, killing 23 people, including four children, our reporter Liam Nolan speaks to young Ukrainians living in the Polish capital Warsaw about whether they think the US-led peace initiative to end the war can succeed.

item.title: McSweeney's 'biggest challenge' on Traitors Ireland
item.description: Siobhán McSweeney hosts The Traitors Ireland - but would she rather be a traitor or a faithful? She tells John Byrne about that as well as her approach to her latest television role.

item.title: Teen who came to Ireland alone reflects on exam success
item.description: It has been a big week for the Class of 2025, with CAO offers following hot on the heals of the Leaving Cert results.

item.title: Watch: Election picnic - views on the race for the Áras
item.description: Electric Picnic - 'the ultimate rock n' roll circus' - is under way at Stradbally, Co Laois.

item.title: Three killed in blaze during protest in Indonesia
item.description: At least three people were killed by a fire started by protesters at a council building in eastern Indonesia's Makassar city, a local official said, after rallies erupted across the country following the death of a motorcycle taxi driver hit by a police vehicle.

item.title: US appeals court finds Trump's global tariffs illegal
item.description: A US appeals court has ruled that many of President Donald Trump's tariffs, which have upended global trade, were illegal - but allowed them to remain in place for now, giving him time to take the fight to the Supreme Court.

item.title: Musical chairs: 5 questions as presenters on the move
item.description: Broadcaster David McCullagh has been announced as the new presenter of Radio 1's Today programme as current presenter Claire Byrne is set to leave RTÉ later this year for Newstalk. Here's what we know so far about the changes.

item.title: Dentistry students studying abroad over college limits
item.description: Seán Hillery from Ennis in Co Clare wants to follow his father into dentistry. However, finding a place to study in Ireland was not possible due to the high number of points he needed after he completed his Leaving Cert in 2023.

item.title: Man arrested over assault on English tourist in Dublin
item.description: A man in his 20s has been arrested in connection with a serious assault in Dublin's Temple Bar last week.

item.title: SIPTU seeks pay increase for workers in childcare sector
item.description: SIPTU has called for direct State investment in the childcare sector to fund a 10% increase in Employment Regulation Order minimum rates and the introduction of higher pay scales.

item.title: RFK Jr. deputy Jim O'Neill to serve as acting leader of U.S. CDC
item.description: Jim O'Neill, a former investor, critic of health regulations and U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s deputy, is taking control of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention following a tumultuous week in which the agency's director was forced out.

item.title: Canada in a 'waiting game' as Trump tariffs case likely headed for U.S. Supreme Court
item.description: A federal appeals court ruled Friday that U.S. President Donald Trump had no legal right to impose sweeping tariffs, but left in place for now his effort to build a protectionist wall around the American economy.

item.title: 'It's catastrophic': Mother reacts to school disruption
item.description: Denise Guihen's twin boys, 13-year-old Finn and Shay, attend Scoil Mochua special school in Clondalkin in Dublin.

item.title: Woman being sued for calling four others 'pretendians' says she's protecting identity
item.description: A First Nations woman is being sued for calling four women "pretendians," with the plaintiffs seeking more than $500,000 in damages and retractions to the heavily publicized comments made about them.

item.title: The €20,000 question: We ask should managers be paid
item.description: The possibility of paid inter-county GAA managers no longer appears to be an issue coming down the tracks, but something that could be put front and centre sooner rather than later. RTÉ Sport spoke to a current inter-county manager, player and committee member to hear their views on such a move.

item.title: First Nations child welfare advocates say work on reform deal will continue with or without Canada
item.description: First Nations child welfare advocates say they will continue to work toward a new child welfare deal as the government weighs its response to an order from the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal to resume talks with them.

item.title: Family of Edmund Fitzgerald's crew on hand as swimmers finish intended route to mark 50 years since sinking
item.description: The Old Mariners Church in Detroit, Mich., was a fitting place to honour an epic journey for a group of swimmers. A day earlier, they also finished a swim that followed the intended route of the Edmund Fitzgerald to mark the 50th anniversary of the sinking of the American freighter.

item.title: Irish woman Gena Heraty released after Haiti kidnapping
item.description: Irish woman Gena Heraty and all those abducted with her have been released following their kidnapping in Haiti earlier this month, her family has confirmed.

item.title: Podcast: The booming live music scene and David has news
item.description: As thousands of music fans descend on Stradbally for Electric Picnic, Behind the Story takes a deep dive into the booming business of Ireland's live music scene.

item.title: Dentists call for cap on international dentistry students
item.description: The Irish Dental Association is calling for a cap on the number of international students taking up dentistry courses in college in Ireland because of the limited number of available places.

item.title: Lord's Day reflection: False virtues
item.description:
As the Church marks the Twenty-second Sunday in Ordinary Time, Abbot Marion Nguyen reflects on "The false virtues: why our culture's strengths are really sins".

Read all

item.title: UN warns Israeli Gaza offensive could be ‘beyond catastrophic’
item.description:
United Nations officials are warning of potentially devastating consequences from Israel’s planned military takeover of Gaza City

Read all

item.title: Deadly Russian strikes devastate Kyiv, kill at least 23
item.description:
The death toll from Russian rocket and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital Kyiv continues to rise. Authorities said Friday that at least 23 people, including children, were killed overnight in the deadliest assault on the city in months.

Read all

item.title: Homelessness is very tough, says Dublin mother of four
item.description: A mother with four children, who have been living in emergency accommodation for just over a year, has said the situation is "very tough".

item.title: Trump withdraws Kamala Harris's Secret Service protection
item.description: The Trump administration has withdrawn former vice president Kamala Harris's Secret Service security protection, a White House official has said.

item.title: Bookmaker linked to Shohei Ohtani's interpreter sentenced to over a year in prison
item.description: A Southern California bookmaker who took thousands of sports bets from the former interpreter for baseball star Shohei Ohtani was sentenced to just over a year in prison Friday.

item.title: A-peeling news for banana workers as Chiquita operations to resume in Panama
item.description: After mass layoffs at banana giant Chiquita's Panama operation this summer threatened the fruit's supply chains, work is set to resume at the plant in Bocas del Toro.

item.title: Murphy to join Gaza aid flotilla aiming to end blockade
item.description: People Before Profit-Solidarity TD Paul Murphy has confirmed he will take part in a planned flotilla seeking to gain access to Gaza next week.

item.title: Six Nations community event aims to reduce stigma around surviving addiction
item.description: Six Nations and surrounding community organizations gathered Wednesday to mark International Overdose Awareness Day.

item.title: Over 5,000 children recorded as homeless last month
item.description: The number of children who are homeless and living in emergency accommodation has exceeded 5,000 for the first time.

item.title: Westbank sells stake in massive Squamish Nation housing development in Vancouver
item.description: Squamish Nation says the Vancouver-based developer has sold its entire stake in the multi-tower Senakw housing project in Kitsilano.

item.title: Diane Foley meets the Pope: How I came to forgive my son's murderer
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV receives Diane Foley alongside writer Colum McCann, with whom she co-authored a book recounting the events surrounding her son’s death and the profound human and spiritual journey she undertook—a painful path of love and a desire to understand, which even led her to meet one of her son’s killers.

Read all

item.title: Shels to host Palace after Conference League draw
item.description: Shelbourne will welcome FA Cup winners Crystal Palace to Dublin and will also face an away trip to play Troy Parrott's AZ Alkmaar after the draw for the Conference League was made this afternoon.

item.title: School seeks court order to have Enoch Burke jailed again
item.description: Management of Wilson's Hospital School in Co Westmeath wants former teacher Enoch Burke jailed again for breaching court orders banning him from attending the site in Co Westmeath.

item.title: ‘Our livelihoods have been cut off’, say West Bank farmers ahead of olive harvest
item.description: In the occupied West Bank village of Kufr Qaddum, *Yousef stands behind a sealed iron gate, cut off from the olive trees that have sustained his family for generations.

item.title: Ukraine: ‘Diplomatic momentum’ at risk amid large-scale Russian strikes
item.description: Large-scale attacks by Russia against civilians in Ukraine could see any hopes of a lasting peace deal there rapidly fade, a senior UN official said during an emergency session of the Security Council on Friday.

item.title: World News in Brief: Executions surge in Iran, nuclear test threat, Burkina Faso declares top official unwelcome
item.description: In Iran, the increase in executions carried out this year indicates that the death penalty is being used as a tool of State intimidation, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) said on Friday.

item.title: Teachers are the ‘guardians of our future’, says UN deputy chief
item.description: In every corner of the world, educators are making choices that echo across generations – influencing everything from the preservation of forests to the writing of poetry, the building of bridges to the holding of peaceful elections.

item.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Push for peace in Ukraine could rapidly fade if large-scale Russian attacks continue
item.description: The UN Security Council met in emergency session in New York on Friday afternoon following overnight strikes early on Thursday by Russia on Ukrainian cities including the capital, which left at least 23 dead, including four children. Assistant Secretary-General Miroslav Jenča told ambassadors that diplomatic momentum towards a possible peace deal was “at risk of rapidly fading” if large-scale attacks by Moscow continue. Follow our live meetings coverage below.

item.title: Despite Taliban ban, over 90 per cent of Afghans support girls’ right to learn
item.description: Despite the ongoing ban on girls’ secondary education, more than 90 per cent of Afghan adults support girls’ right to be in class, according to a new alert from the UN’s gender equality agency, UN Women.

item.title: Sudan: Guterres calls for ceasefire in El Fasher, deplores ‘relentless’ militia attacks
item.description: The UN Secretary-General appealed on Friday for an immediate ceasefire in and around the besieged Sudanese city of El Fasher, where hundreds of thousands of civilians have been trapped for over a year.

item.title: The descent into ‘a massive famine’ in Gaza has begun, relief agencies warn
item.description: Amid reports of increased Israeli military operations across Gaza City on Friday, UN aid agencies repeated urgent warnings of ongoing famine and a likely rise in preventable disease, linked to the dire living conditions in the war-shattered enclave.

item.title: Ahern not ruling out presidency run, Chambers backs Gavin
item.description: Former taoiseach Bertie Ahern has said he is not ruling himself out of seeking a nomination for president after expressing disappointment with the Fianna Fáil leadership for failing to express support for him.

item.title: McCullagh moves to Today programme as Byrne to leave RTÉ
item.description: Broadcaster David McCullagh has been announced as the new presenter of Radio 1's Today programme as its current presenter Claire Byrne is set to leave RTÉ later this year.

item.title: Protests erupt in Indonesia after motorcyclist killed by police vehicle in clashes
item.description: Hundreds of Indonesians protested at sites across Jakarta on Friday over the death of a civilian hit by a police vehicle, triggering calls for police reform in the first major test for President Prabowo Subianto's nearly year-old government.

item.title: Human Fraternity Fellowship continues legacy of Pope Francis in new generations
item.description:
The second edition of the Human Fraternity Fellowship program, inspired by the Document of Human Fraternity signed by Pope Francis and Grand Imam Al-Tayeb of Al-Azhar in 2019, leads 10 student leaders to Jakarta, Indonesia, to prepare “the next generation of leaders to engage across cultural and religious divides.”

Read all

item.title: Watch: Electric Picnic festival goers reveal top acts
item.description: Electric Picnic 2025 is officially underway, with 80,000 festivalgoers set to descend on Stradbally, Co Laois, across the weekend. RTÉ News finds out which acts people are looking forward to seeing the most.

item.title: Pope: Proclamation of Christ is mission of every Christian
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV meets with members of the St. Andrew School of Evangelization, and invites all Christians to embrace our mission to proclaim Jesus Christ.

Read all

item.title: Galway cinema closed after damage caused by heavy rain
item.description: The EYE Cinema in Galway has temporarily closed after heavy rain caused extensive damage to the building yesterday.

item.title: Initial stages of Gaza City attack under way, says Israel
item.description: The Israeli military has said it is "operating with great force on the outskirts of Gaza City" as it confirmed that the initial stages of its attack on the Palestinian territory's largest city is under way.

item.title: Death toll in Ukraine's capital rises to 23 after Russian attack, peace talks stalled
item.description: The death toll in a major Russian missile and drone strike on the Ukrainian capital rose to 23, including four children, officials said Friday, as U.S.-led efforts to end the three-year war remain stuck in apparent limbo.

item.title: Korean bishops relaunch Pro-Life Movement amid abortion, euthanasia debates
item.description:
The Catholic Church in South Korea is set to relaunch the “Pro-Life Movement” nationwide as bishops and organizations intensify opposition to proposed legislative changes on abortion and growing calls for euthanasia.

Read all

item.title: How these 4 nations in B.C. advanced Indigenous rights and title through the courts
item.description: With the majority of B.C. having been settled without treaties or the consent of First Nations, Indigenous people in the province have taken to the courts to affirm their rights and title, resulting in landmark cases that are studied around the world.

item.title: Mystery surrounding Kyran Durnin disappearance continues
item.description: Tomorrow marks one year to the day that schoolboy Kyran Durnin was first reported missing. On 30 August 2024, Kyran, who would now be nine years old, was reported missing from his home in Drogheda, Co Louth.

item.title: Thai PM Paetongtarn Shinawatra ordered removed from office over compromising phone call
item.description: Thailand's Constitutional Court on Friday dismissed Paetongtarn Shinawatra from her position as prime minister, ruling that as the country's leader she violated constitutional rules on ethics in a phone call with Cambodia's Senate President Hun Sen.

item.title: Israel says it's launching an attack on Gaza City, halts humanitarian pauses
item.description: The Israeli military said on Friday that it has begun preliminary operations and the initial stages of a planned offensive on Gaza city, adding that it is currently operating with great force on the outskirts. The body of a hostage was also recovered, the military said.

item.title: New appeal issued over missing schoolboy Kyran Durnin
item.description: Almost a year to the day that schoolboy Kyran Durnin was first reported missing from his home in Drogheda, Co Louth, gardaí have renewed their appeal for information on the case.

item.title: South Korea sees high-profile indictments of former PM, ex-president's wife months after political chaos
item.description: Former South Korean prime minister Han Duck-soo was indicted on charges of abetting insurrection and committing perjury, a spokesperson for the prosecutors said in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: Small businesses that relied on duty-free U.S. shipping wonder if they can survive without it
item.description: As of Friday, Canada's small businesses can no longer ship small packages to the U.S. duty-free — and some online sellers are worried that their companies won't survive the hit.

item.title: Zelensky urges more pressure on Putin after Kyiv attack
item.description: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has urged Western allies to send a "strong joint signal" to Vladimir Putin, after Russia killed 23 people in one of its deadliest attacks on Kyiv since the start of the war.

item.title: Pope to Augustinians: 'Peace begins with what we say and do'
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV sends a video message to the Augustinian Province of Saint Thomas of Villanova on the feast of their spiritual father, and invites everyone to listen to God's loving voice, which alone can bring peace.

Read all

item.title: Special schools hit as SNAs refuse to pass picket line
item.description: A special school in Carlow was closed today while most of the children attending a special school in Dublin were asked to stay at home after Special Needs Assistants (SNAs) refused to pass picket lines of striking school secretaries and caretakers.

item.title: Chaos swirls at U.S. CDC amid messy Trump admin effort to oust director
item.description: The top U.S. public health agency was left reeling and leaderless as the White House works to expel its handpicked director from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, while three senior officials were escorted from the agency's headquarters on Thursday.

item.title: '60s Scoop survivor travels from New Zealand to Manitoba to meet his birth mother
item.description: Jonathan Hooker returned home to a warm welcome from friends, family, and supporters at the Winnipeg airport on Wednesday.

item.title: About That | Why the ICC is in the fight of its life with Trump
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump has imposed sanctions against four International Criminal Court (ICC) judges. About That producer Anand Ram examines the complicated relationship between the U.S. and the ICC and explains why the Trump administration is now ramping up attacks against the international body. Images provided by Getty Images, The Canadian Press and Reuters.

item.title: A doctor at the only Christian hospital in Gaza: ‘War is death’
item.description:
Dr. Maher Ayyad describes the current dire situation of hospitals in the Strip: People “are living in small tents without any services—no electricity, no water supply, and, despite food recently coming across the border, no food.”

Read all

item.title: Kanehsatà:ke council asks Federal Court to back up its authority after cancelled election
item.description: Tensions are flaring in the Mohawk community of Kanehsatà:ke nearly one month after an election was abruptly called off, leaving disagreement and uncertainty over who is in charge and how to organize another vote.

item.title: U.N. warns of worsening famine in Gaza
item.description:
Famine has taken hold in Gaza and is expected to spread further by the end of September, a top U.N. humanitarian has said.

Read all

item.title: Pope to Christian politicians: ‘Values’ without Christ cannot change the world
item.description:
In a message to French elected officials, Pope Leo insists on the need for Christian political leaders to turn to Jesus, to live their faith without compromise and bear witness to Him in order to face modern challenges and make the world a better place.

Read all

item.title: World News In Brief: Iran sanctions, Yemen floods appeal, new SDG advocates
item.description: The United Nations confirmed on Thursday that France, Germany and the United Kingdom have initiated a process that could lead to the reimposition of sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme within the next 30 days.

item.title: Sudan: A staggering 30 million are in need, as war grinds on
item.description: Humanitarians continue to push for more support for Sudan amid ongoing conflict, rising malnutrition and a cholera outbreak, a senior UN aid coordination official said on Thursday in New York.

item.title: ‘The people of Haiti are in a perfect storm of suffering,’ warns UN chief
item.description: State authority is crumbling across Haiti while gang violence engulfs the capital Port-au-Prince and beyond, “paralysing daily life and forcing families to flee,” UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the Security Council on Thursday.

item.title: Security Council: UN peacekeeping mission in Lebanon extended for a ‘final time’
item.description: The UN peacekeeping mission which patrols the so-called Blue Line of separation between Israel and Lebanon received the unanimous support of the Security Council on Thursday to extend through 31 December next year.

item.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Haiti ‘shamefully overlooked’, warns Guterres
item.description: Haitians are enduring a “perfect storm of suffering” the UN Secretary-General António Guterres told the Security Council on Thursday as gang violence continues to paralyse daily life across the island. Around 1.3 million people – half of them children – have fled their homes and six million are relying on humanitarian assistance. Follow our live Meetings Coverage as the latest crisis debate unfolds.

item.title: Gaza death and destruction ‘without parallel in recent times’: Guterres
item.description: UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Thursday renewed his call for a ceasefire in Gaza, greater humanitarian access and the release of all hostages, as the enclave faces yet another deadly escalation.

item.title: Ukraine: Toddler among four children killed in Russia’s attacks on Kyiv
item.description: Russia’s latest deadly attacks on Ukrainian cities overnight including the capital, Kyiv, left four children dead and dozens injured, UN aid agencies reported on Thursday.

item.title: Church in US in mourning following Minneapolis tragedy
item.description:
The church in the United States expresses its grief and condolences following Wednesday's tragedy in Minneapolis, where a young man opened fire during Mass at Annunciation Catholic School. The attack resulted in the deaths of two children and around seventeen injured before the shooter took his own life.

Read all

item.title: Africa to host landmark world congress 2026 for Catholic media practitioners in Rwanda
item.description:
SIGNIS Africa President, Fr. Prof. Walter Chikwendu Ihejirika, has said that the recent SECAM Plenary Assembly of Africa’s Catholic Bishops has warmly welcomed the Catholic communication association’s plans to hold the SIGNIS World Congress in Kigali, Rwanda, next year.

Read all

item.title: Eskasoni First Nation pays tribute to first responders
item.description: Chief and council held a special event Wednesday honouring those who have been on-call for Eskasoni's emergencies.

item.title: Saugeen First Nation looks to the future after Supreme Court denies appeal in dispute over Ontario beach
item.description: The chief of an Ontario First Nation says he's looking forward to a future free from legal battles after the Supreme Court announced Thursday it won't hear an appeal of lower court decisions that confirm the band's ownership of a disputed piece of beachfront.

item.title: Inuit innovators turn to AI to revitalize Inuktitut
item.description: AingA.I.'s founder and CEO Kirt Ejesiak says he doesn’t really see much Inuit representation in the AI field, so he wanted to create something that’ll benefit Inuit in the form of an AI-powered Inuktitut translation and interpretation app. But he also urges caution around data sovereignty.

item.title: New building for Saskatoon's Cree bilingual school set to open its doors to students
item.description: Saskatoon's rebuilt Awâsisak kâ-nîmîhtocik St. Francis Cree School will welcome around 600 students on Sept. 2, placing an emphasis on traditional Indigenous teachings.

item.title: Sask. Cree community fighting to officially become Canada's newest First Nation
item.description: The Peter Chapman Band in central Saskatchewan is pushing for recognition as an independent band, a move community leaders say would right a historical wrong.

item.title: Pope Leo expresses sorrow over shooting at Catholic school in Minneapolis
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV expresses profound sorrow over the murder of two children and the injuring of 17 others at the Annunciation Catholic church and school complex in the US city of Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Read all

item.title: Cardinal Parolin: Many interests are preventing a solution to the Gaza tragedy
item.description:
Responding to questions asked by journalists following the Mass on the Memorial of Saint Monica, celebrated at the Basilica of Saint Augustine in Campo Marzio, Rome, Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Parolin expresses hopes in echoing Pope Leo's appeal that a “collective punishment” in the Middle East would be avoided, and that a ceasefire and “safe access” to humanitarian aid would be achieved.

Read all

item.title: One last appeal to save a man's life
item.description:
In less than 24 hours, Curtis Windom is scheduled to be executed in the United States and, Kevin Jackson from the Community of Sant'Eigidio, makes one final appeal for clemency to be granted and Curtis' life to be spared.

Read all

item.title: Heavy monsoon rains lead to flooding in India, Pakistan
item.description:
Dozens of people are killed when a landslide caused by heavy rains strikes a pilgrim route near a Hindu shrine in India.

Read all

item.title: Fr. Romanelli: Gazan Christians remain with those who suffer
item.description:
As Pope Leo XIV appeals for peace in Gaza, Fr. Gabriel Romanelli, parish priest of the only Catholic parish in Gaza, tells Vatican News that Christians in the enclave are committed to serving those in need, asking people to pray for an end to the war.

Read all

item.title: 'No more excuses': Minnesota lawmakers and advocates plead for gun control
Latin America and Caribbean: Millions more children could face poverty due to climate change
item.description: Climate change could push at least 5.9 million more children and young people in Latin America and the Caribbean into poverty by 2030 unless governments act now.

item.title: Sudan: ‘Devastating tragedy’ for children in El Fasher after 500 days of siege
item.description: After 500 days of siege, the city of El Fasher in Sudan’s North Darfur has become an epicentre of child suffering, with malnutrition, disease and violence claiming young lives every day, the UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF) said on Wednesday.

item.title: Pakistan floods leave villages cut off as monsoon devastation continues
item.description: Relentless monsoon rains continue to wreak havoc across Pakistan, leaving villages cut off, homes destroyed and families struggling to access food, clean water and medical care.

item.title: UN calls for decisive steps to end conflict as Gaza and West Bank crises deepen
item.description: Nearly two years of war in Gaza along with continued violence and settlement expansion in the occupied West Bank - and talk of an imminent takeover by Israel of the whole Strip - formed the backdrop to a Security Council meeting on Wednesday, as UN officials underscored the need to end the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

item.title: Iraq unveils historic migration plan to boost development and stability
item.description: Iraq has taken an historic step with the launch of its first ever national migration plan, designed to promote safe, orderly and regular pathways for Iraqis returning home and around 370,000 migrants living and working inside the country.

item.title: Hunger and disease in Gaza will only worsen from ‘man-made’ famine: WHO
item.description: The UN World Health Organization (WHO) on Wednesday issued a new warning over the deadly impacts of the ongoing Israeli blockade of Gaza on people there now suffering starvation.

item.title: UN peacekeeping mandate in Lebanon faces scrutiny ahead of Security Council vote
item.description: Following a devastating 15-month conflict between Israel and Hezbollah militants focused on southern Lebanon, the November 2024 cessation of hostilities created a fragile calm along the Blue Line separating the two countries.

item.title: Apply for the 2026 ACME Workshop!
item.description: Applications for the Vatican Observatory Foundation's 2026 ACME workshop will be accepted during September

item.title: Mary’s Meals reaches new milestone: meals for over three million children
item.description:
The official announcement of the milestone will be made on 8 September, the feast of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Founder and CEO Magnus MacFarlane-Barrow, speaking at the Rimini Meeting, tells Vatican Media: “We feel called to stand with those parts of the world where people have no voice.”

Read all

item.title: Searchers from Manitoba arrive in Edmonton to join search for missing Indigenous teen
item.description: A group of Manitoba-based searchers have arrived in Alberta to scour the North Saskatchewan River for an Edmonton teen who has been missing all summer.

item.title: Pope Leo joins Jerusalem Patriarchs’ call for peace in Gaza
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV has united his voice to the Latin and Greek Orthodox Patriarchs’ joint appeal for an end to the war in Gaza and for humanitarian aid to flow freely into the enclave.

Read all

item.title: Pope at Audience: ‘Christian love is not evasion but decision’
item.description:
During his weekly General Audience, Pope Leo reflects on Jesus’ arrest in the Garden of Gethsemane, highlighting that in these moments of fear, injustice and loneliness, God is present.

Read all

item.title: Airstrikes destroy Myanmar church, but bishop says faith remains unbroken
item.description:
Bishop Lucius Hre Kung of Hakha says the faith of Catholics in Chin State, Myanmar, remains resilient after airstrikes by the Burmese army destroyed the Church of Christ the King in Falam earlier this year.

Read all

item.title: A West Bank mother’s testimonial
item.description:
Stay or go? Palestinian Christians in Bethlehem—and throughout the West Bank—face this dilemma. Shahinda Nassar shares the pain she feels when her 16-year-old daughter presses her to leave Bethlehem, as well as the obligation she feels to stay and maintain the Christian presence.

Read all

item.title: 'It's our right': This Sask. Cree community is fighting to become newest First Nation in Canada
item.description: The Peter Chapman Band in central Saskatchewan is building new homes and infrastructure as part of a master plan for a new First Nation. The effort is part of a renewed push for recognition as an independent band, a move the community says would right a historical wrong.

item.title: 'We're in a war zone': On patrol with security in a First Nation gripped by tensions
item.description: CBC News accompanied Kanesatake Perimeter Security for a closer look at a team some refer to as the “last line of defence” in a First Nation territory west of Montreal that has no local police force, but faced increased incidents such as arson and vehicle accidents over the past three years.

item.title: Community safety guardian training for Yukon First Nations now offered at Yukon University
item.description: Yukon First Nation-owned consultancy firm House of Wolf & Associates has teamed up with Yukon University to offer a community safety guardian training program, intended to help create safer Yukon communities.

item.title: Rediscovering the potential of wild rice at harvest time
item.description: Late summer or early fall is harvesting season for wild rice, or manoomin as it's known in Anishinaabemowin, and Manitoba is one of Canada's largest producers.

item.title: Stateside: Monday, Aug. 25, 2025
item.description: April Baer interviews Br. Guy Consolmagno for the Stateside podcast.

item.title: Colum McCann: 'Distance between two people is always only a story'
item.description:
At the Rimini Meeting, writers Colum McCann, Javier Cercas, and Dr. Paolo Ruffini share their thoughts on the power of stories to unite people and build communion where division seems to prevail.

Read all

item.title: Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew: There can be no peace without justice
item.description:
On the sidelines of the Rimini meeting, the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople laments the war in Ukraine, calling it “a fratricidal war—a scandal for the Christian world, and especially for the Orthodox Church.”

Read all

item.title: Bishop Lodiong’s passion plea for peace and dialogue in South Sudan
item.description:
South Sudan’s Catholic Bishop of Yei Diocese, Bishop Alex Lodiong Sakor Eyobo, has emphasised that there is no alternative to dialogue and sitting together at the round table to resolve the country’s political differences.

Read all

item.title: Caritas Internationalis: Peace and respect for human rights go hand-in-hand
item.description:
The Director of Integral Human Development for Caritas Internationalis explains that the organization’s statement used strong words to call for an end to violence and promote the protection of human rights both in the region and around the world.

Read all

item.title: New Kuujjuaq residence ready to welcome students
item.description: Built in the heart of the community, the two-storey residence can accommodate up to 84 people. It features communal spaces for studying and holding cultural gatherings. It also features a cafeteria, a gym, a daycare and modular lodgings that can accommodate single occupants or entire families.

item.title: Former Oromocto First Nation chief, 8 others, to stand trial on assault, break-in charges
item.description: Former chief Shelley Sabattis, along with eight others, will go to trial on charges of assault and breaking and entering.

item.title: Families of Hamas hostages protest across Israel
item.description:
Families of hostages held by Hamas stage protests in Israel, demanding government action to secure their release and bring about a ceasefire in Gaza.

Read all

item.title: ‘I desire silence:’ Sr. Veronica and search for life's meaning at Swedish convent
item.description:
Sister Veronica lived in a French lay order and was later sent to Sweden. In Rögle, she has met people who are not Catholic, but who nevertheless visit the Dominican sisters’ convent to find themselves and silence.

Read all

item.title: World News in Brief: More deaths in Ukraine, lengthy detentions in Egypt, AI governance, US postal tariffs
item.description: More civilians have been killed and injured in Ukraine following recent hostilities and attacks across the country, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Tuesday in an update.

item.title: One in four still lacks access to safe drinking water and sanitation
item.description: Despite progress over the past decade, billions worldwide still lack access to safe drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene, leaving them vulnerable to disease and social exclusion, according to a UN report released on Tuesday.

item.title: Thailand grants work rights to long-term refugees from Myanmar, UN welcomes resolution
item.description: A new resolution by the Thai Government that will allow long-staying refugees from Myanmar to work legally in the country was welcomed on Tuesday by the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, as a significant boost to the national economy.

item.title: Killing of journalists in Gaza hospital attack ‘should shock the world’: UN rights office
item.description: The killing of five more Palestinian journalists in Gaza by Israeli forces – bringing the total killed overall to 247 since the war began – should shock the world into action, the UN human rights office said on Tuesday.

item.title: Greek and Latin Patriarchs of Jerusalem: 'Time to end the cycle of violence'
item.description:
Following the Israeli government’s approved plan to take control of Gaza, the Greek Orthodox and Latin Patriarchates of Jerusalem call for an end to the war, stressing “there has been enough destruction” and highlighting the need for "families on all sides—who have suffered for far too long” to be able to start healing.

Read all

item.title: Pope’s theme for 2026 World Day of Peace: ‘Peace be with you all’
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV releases the theme for the 2026 World Day of Peace, “Peace be with you all: Towards an ‘unarmed and disarming’ peace,” as the Vatican Publishing House produces a book entitled “And Let There Be Peace.”

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo XIV receives Judge Mohamed Abdelsalam
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV holds a private audience with Judge Mohamed Abdelsalam, Secretary-General of the Muslim Council of Elders and of the Zayed Award for Human Fraternity.

Read all

item.title: Grad student Rebecca Dudley’s summer studies included an audience with Pope Leo XIV
item.description: Rebecca Dudley was one of 25 students who attended the 2025 Vatican Observatory Summer School.

item.title: Cardinal Parolin: "We are appalled at what is happening in Gaza"
item.description:
Cardinal Pietro Parolin, speaking in Naples at the opening of the 75th National Liturgical Week, expresses his deep concern over the Israeli bombing of Gaza, saying it makes "no sense" and warning of the worsening humanitarian crisis.

Read all

item.title: Cardinal Parolin: Liturgy is a 'place' of closeness, hope, sign of peace
item.description:
At the opening of the 75th National Liturgical Week in Naples, Cardinal Secretary of State Pietro Parolin reflects on how the liturgy embodies the Jubilee Year’s central theme of hope, interwoven with faith and charity.

Read all

item.title: Caritas Internationalis: Famine in Gaza violates Genocide Convention
item.description:
Caritas Internationalis warns that the man-made famine in Gaza constitutes a flagrant breach of international law, including the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, and calls for urgent global action to uphold human dignity and protect civilian life.

Read all

item.title: Caritas Pakistan provides aid to the thousands suffering from floods
item.description:
Caritas Pakistan Executive Director reports that 2,500 flood-affected families—some 17,500 people—are expected to receive aid, in the form of food packages, hygiene kits, and drinking water.

Read all

item.title: Twenty killed in Israeli strike on Gaza hospital
item.description:
Palestinian health officials say that at least 20 people have been killed in strikes on the Nassa Hospital in Gaza’s southern city of Khan Younis.

Read all

item.title: Gaza: UN calls for probe following deadly strikes on Nasser Hospital
item.description: The head of the World Health Organization (WHO) renewed his call for a ceasefire in Gaza following two deadly Israeli air strikes on the Nasser Hospital in the southern Strip on Monday.

item.title: Putting water management at the centre of the climate change fight
item.description: Some 2.2 billion people worldwide still lack access to safely managed drinking water services, according to the World Health Organization (WHO) - an increasingly urgent challenge as demand for safer access to the vital resource grows.

item.title: UN urges renewed solidarity eight years after forced exodus of Rohingya
item.description: Monday marks eight years since the mass displacement of Rohingya from Rakhine state in Myanmar and the United Nations is calling for greater international solidarity with the mainly Muslim minority community.

item.title: DR Congo: The doctor who couldn’t leave Goma
item.description: In the days leading up to the fall of Goma, the capital of North Kivu in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, Dr. Thierno Balde slept with a helmet and bulletproof vest beside his bed as shells rattled the walls of his hotel.

item.title: Pope commemorates 400th anniversary of first Lithuanian priest in India
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV commemorates the anniversary and witness of Fr. Andrius Rudamina, a Lithuanian-born Jesuit who traveled more than 5,000 miles to India in 1625 to preach the Gospel.

Read all

item.title: Pope: Altar servers help lead faithful into sacred Mystery of Mass
item.description:
Meeting with altar servers from France, Pope Leo XIV laments the country’s lack of priests and upholds the ministry of young people at the altar, saying the dignity of their service helps lead people into the sacred greatness of the Mystery.

Read all

item.title: Pope Leo XIV to inaugurate Laudato Si’ Village in Castel Gandolfo
item.description:
Marking the tenth anniversary of the papal encyclical Laudato si’, Pope Leo XIV is scheduled to open Castel Gandolfo’s Laudato Si’ Village, a place where spirituality, education, and care for creation come together.

Read all

item.title: Church in Thailand equips seminarians for deaf ministry
item.description:
The Catholic Church in Thailand is stepping up efforts to strengthen pastoral care for the Deaf, beginning with a training program for seminarians at Fatima Minor Seminary in the Archdiocese of Thare-Nongseng in the northeast of the country.

Read all

item.title: We remember Pope Pius XII’s call for peace, 86 years on
item.description:
Exactly 86 years ago, Pope Pius XII appealed for peace in an attempt to help avoid World War Two. His words still resonate today.

Read all

item.title: The dire situation in Mozambique’s northern Cabo Delgado
item.description:
More than 50,000 people have been displaced in Mozambique’s northern Cabo Delgado province in recent weeks following a new wave of terrorist attacks.

Read all

item.title: Pope prays for Mozambique: that the country’s leaders restore peace and security
item.description:
After the Sunday Angelus, Pope Leo turns his thoughts to Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado province and to Ukraine, urging prayer and closeness for peoples wounded by violence and war.

Read all

item.title: Tombs of the Unknown Scientists (re-run)
item.description: In the “Holy Land” of Kentucky stands a monument to a man who cared for and buried the victims of a cholera epidemic, and who might have done some science.

item.title: Aristarchus Plateau emerging
item.description: When the moon is about 12 days past new a dramatic region can be found on the terminator just north of the equator emerging from its long night. It is...

item.title: Guterres in Japan: ‘Humanity is strongest when we stand as one’
item.description: World Expos are not just feel-good exhibitions, “they are invitations to tell our stories,” The UN chief told festival goers in Osaka, Japan, which is hosting Expo 2025.

item.title: Momentum builds towards marine biodiversity treaty, as experts convene in New York
item.description: Delegates from around the world met at UN Headquarters in New York this week to advance the long-awaited high seas biodiversity treaty, with discussions ranging from rules of procedure, to the creation of a clearing-house mechanism and the location of the treaty’s secretariat.

item.title: UN agencies warn of rising heat stress risks for workers worldwide
item.description: Extreme heat is fast becoming one of the biggest threats to workers’ health and livelihoods, the World Health Organization (WHO) and World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warned on Friday.

item.title: Monsoon floods kill more than 700 in Pakistan, with heavy rains set to continue
item.description: Heavy monsoon rains and flash floods have killed at least 739 people across Pakistan since late June, displacing thousands and destroying homes and crops, with more severe weather expected in the weeks ahead, according to UN agencies and national authorities.

item.title: From the Vatican Observatory Faith and Science pages (Younger Readers) — How I got to NASA (the Charles F. Bolden, Jr. story)
item.description: From the Faith & Science Resource Center (Younger Readers): How Charles F. Bolden, Jr. came to pilot the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit and be NASA’s head.

item.title: Fr. Richard D’Souza named Director of Vatican Observatory | The Society of Jesus
item.description: Pope Leo XIV has appointed Fr. Richard D’Souza, SJ as Director of the Vatican Observatory. Fr. D’Souza has been a staff member at the Observatory since...

item.title: ‘Pope’s astronomer’ rates Tekapo dark skies highly
item.description: The man known as the “the Pope’s astronomer” has a high regard for the Dark Sky Project at Tekapo.

item.title: Observing Asteroids at VATT, Part 4a
item.description: Dr. Larry Lebofsky discusses a typical trip up to the VATT, how dangerously close the Frye fire came to the VATT, and a bit of astronomy history.

item.title: Faith and Science: A resource book for the Archdiocese of Louisville
item.description: A new addition to the Faith & Science Resource Center: A resource book for a diocese.

item.title: What to expect from Zelenskyy’s next meeting with Trump, backed by European leaders
item.description: When Zelenskyy returns to the Oval Office on Monday, at least a half-dozen European leaders will join him in a high-profile display of unity. After meeting with Putin on Friday, Trump aligned himself with Russian positions, triggering fears that Ukraine could be pressured to accept Moscow’s terms. John Yang speaks with William Taylor, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, for more on what to expect. PBS News is supported by - https://www.pbs.org/newshour/about/funders. Hosted on Acast. See acast.com/privacy

item.title: New director at the Vatican Observatory – Lutheran Alliance for Faith, Science and Technology
item.description: Pope Leo XIV appointed Father Richard Anthony D’Souza, S.J., as the new director of the Vatican Observatory, effective Sept. 19.

item.title: From dough to dough: Bahraini chefs rise with sweet, spicy success
item.description: In the heart of Bahrain in the Persian Gulf, a woman with a passion for sweet treats transformed her love for baking into a thriving business.

item.title: Earths (plural) at Notre Dame
item.description: At Notre Dame: Discussing science’s role in the story of the Copernican system, the idea of a universe full of other Earths, and Earth’s place in the...

item.title: Plastic pollution treaty talks adjourn, but countries want to ‘remain at the table’: UNEP chief
item.description: The international push for consensus on a legally binding deal to end plastic pollution proved beyond the grasp of weary UN Member States meeting in Geneva on Friday, as they agreed to resume discussions at a future date.

item.title: A two-way street: Reversing the brain drain in Somalia
item.description: For many countries in crisis, brain drain can feel like an unbreakable loop. Armed conflict, climate shocks and economic downturn drive out local experts who take with them the know-how that is essential to reversing the crisis.

item.title: Canada is strengthening defence ties with Finland and Sweden. What can they teach us?
7 Articles to get an overview of Church and Science by Christopher M. Graney – Aleteia
item.description: We invite you to take a look at this brief series, and finish with a better understanding of 2,000 years of (sometimes messy) cooperation.

item.title: Peacekeepers find weapons trove in southern Lebanon, as drought threatens millions
item.description: UN peacekeepers in southern Lebanon have uncovered rocket launchers, mortar rounds and other unauthorized weapons, while the country grapples with a severe drought, threatening millions with life-threatening water shortages.

item.title: Pope Leo returns to Castel Gandolfo for Assumption holiday weekend
item.description: The VO got the smallest of mentions in this article

item.title: How nuclear technology can help fight seafood fraud
item.description: Across the globe, consumers and small-scale fishers alike are facing a growing challenge: seafood fraud.

item.title: The world has the tools to end Haiti’s crisis – it’s time to use them
item.description: During her final briefing as resident and humanitarian coordinator for Haiti, Ulrika Richardson struggled to describe the realities of life in Haiti.

item.title: Celebrating youth: ‘When young people take the lead, everyone gains’
item.description: Colourful blocks for stacking or perhaps an abacus for counting – these are the sorts of tactile objects one might expect to see in a kindergarten classroom.

item.title: Skyward by David H. Levy – August 2025
item.description: David Levy discusses observing at this year's Adirondack Astronomy Retreat

item.title: From crisis to cultivation: Haiti’s farmers build resilience one seed at a time
item.description: For years, low-quality seeds have been a concern in Haiti, with continual climate shocks and political insecurity adding to the existing challenges that farmers face in their attempts to grow food.
